title: Walking in Truth
shortSummary: 3 John is a personal letter from the Apostle John to Gaius, commending him for his faithfulness and hospitality toward traveling Christian brethren. The chapter contrasts Gaius' godly example with the divisive behavior of Diotrephes, emphasizing the importance of walking in truth and supporting fellow believers.
timeline: c. AD 90-95 - Late first century, during the apostolic era when John was writing to early Christian communities

keyCharacters.name: John the Elder
keyCharacters.description: The author of the letter, an apostle and spiritual leader addressing issues in the early church.

keyCharacters.name: Gaius
keyCharacters.description: The recipient of the letter, commended for his faithfulness, hospitality, and walking in the truth.

keyCharacters.name: Diotrephes
keyCharacters.description: A church leader who loves to have preeminence, refuses to welcome John's messengers, and causes division.

keyCharacters.name: Demetrius
keyCharacters.description: A well-regarded believer who has a good testimony from all and is commended by John.

definitions.definition: In the KJV context, charity refers to Christian love expressed through generous hospitality and care for others.
A desire for supremacy or highest rank, often leading to pride and division within the church.
Partners or coworkers who assist in advancing the truth of the gospel.
To live consistently according to the teachings and reality of God's Word.

outline.heading: Greeting and Commendation of Gaius
outline.description: John opens with a warm greeting to Gaius, expressing joy over his steadfastness in truth and spiritual prosperity, highlighting the importance of living faithfully in the Christian walk.

outline.heading: Praise for Gaius' Hospitality
outline.description: John commends Gaius for his faithful support of traveling brethren and strangers, emphasizing the biblical mandate to show hospitality and support those who serve the gospel.

outline.heading: Rebuke of Diotrephes
outline.description: John confronts the divisive actions of Diotrephes, who rejects apostolic authority, refuses to welcome brethren, and exerts control by casting out those who disagree, warning of the dangers of pride and selfish ambition.

outline.heading: Exhortation to Choose Good
outline.description: John urges believers to imitate what is good, affirming that doing good is from God, and commends Demetrius as an example of a faithful and well-regarded servant of the truth.

outline.heading: Closing Remarks and Greetings
outline.description: John concludes with a personal note expressing his desire to visit Gaius soon and sends greetings from mutual friends, underscoring the fellowship and peace found in the Christian community.

application: Cultivate a consistent walk in the truth by aligning daily life with Scripture and living transparently before God and others.
Practice hospitality and support for those who labor in the gospel, recognizing it as a vital ministry in the body of Christ.
Reject pride and selfish ambition that seek preeminence, instead promoting unity and humility within the church.

keyVerses.text: I have no greater joy than to hear that my children walk in truth.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the deep joy and satisfaction that comes from seeing believers live faithfully according to God's truth.

keyVerses.text: Beloved, follow not that which is evil, but that which is good. He that doeth good is of God: but he that doeth evil hath not seen God.
keyVerses.significance: A clear exhortation to choose good over evil, affirming that good works are evidence of a genuine relationship with God.

keyVerses.text: We therefore ought to receive such, that we might be fellowhelpers to the truth.
keyVerses.significance: This verse stresses the importance of welcoming and supporting those who serve the gospel, partnering together to advance the truth.
